Have i already posted/blogged this? I dunno. I first saw this in about '89, when someone faxed it to the tech school i was at. It was taped to the bathroom door for a while. It was a terrible thing to put on a bathroom door. You'd be waiting for a shot to pee on the break and have to stand there reading the poopie list, and you'd be laughing and it made you have to pee worse. All recently made poopie lists are missing the most important one, which i have included, in bold, at the bottom. The (Compleat) Poopie List GHOST POOPIE: The kind where you feel the poopie come out, but there is no poopie in the toilet. CLEAN POOPIE: The kind where you poopie it out, see it in the toilet, but there is nothing on the toilet paper. SECOND WAVE POOPIE: This happens when you're done pooping, have pulled your underwear up to your knees and you realize you have to poopie some more. POP-A-VEIN-IN-YOUR-FOREHEAD POOPIE: The kind where you strain so hard you practically have a stroke. LINCOLN LOG POOPIE: This kind of poopie is so huge, you are afraid to flush without breaking it up with your pencil. GASSEY POOPIE: It is so noisy that everyone within earshot is giggling. DRINKER POOPIE: The kind of poopie you have after a long night of drinking. It's most noticeable trait is the skid marks at the bottom of the toilet bowl. CORN POOPIE: (self explanatory) GEE-I-WISH-I-COULD-POOPIE POOPIE: The kind where you want to poopie but all you could do is sit on the toilet and fart a few times. SPINAL TAP POOPIE: This kind hurts so bad coming out, you swear it is leaving sideways. WET CHEEKS POOPIE (aka POWER DUMP): The kind that comes out so fast, your behind is splashed with toilet water. LIQUID POOPIE: The kind where yellowish-brown liquid shoots out and splashes all over the toilet bowl and you. UPPER CLASS POOPIE: The kind of poopie that does not smell. SUPRISE POOPIE: You are not even at the toilet because you are positive you will only fart, but...(oops!) a poopie. DANGLING POOPIE: This poopie refuses to drop even though you know you are done pooping. You just hope that a shake or two will cut it loose. ATOMIC POOPIE: The kind that burns on the way out and it still burns hours after you poopie. (I recall this one being the MEXICAN FOOD POOPIE) THE FISHERMAN'S BOBBER POOPIE: The one little poopie that fools you and hides when you flush, and then when you come back the little poopie is floating around still. This poopie is closely related to the GHOST POOPIE. I still laugh my fucking ass off at the poopie list.

Bad Old World Dear Justin, I know it's been a long time Remember all those nights we spent sitting up talking in your front room About leaving this worn out world and starting again far away in a better place Well that's where I am now - but still thinking about you Chorus: I'm never going back there I'm never going back to the bad old world I was travelling with Laurel way up on the north coast She's got family living up here in a nearby town We found a piece of land that looks out towards the north sea islands across the bay And the sun is shining on the water today as I look out of our front door Chorus: I'm never going back there I'm never going back to the bad old world Are you still scared of the future? Well, that doesn't surprise me You could come up and stay here a while, back off from the killing wheel I used to think it was me who'd somehow sold out or given in on some almighty cause, But what difference would it make? It feels good to be out here. Chorus: I'm never going back there I'm never going back to the bad old world (by New Model Army. From the Love of Hopeless Causes album) I dont know why i put it here. Its one of my favorite NMA songs. My life may be shitty, but i still wanna shake my fist at all the assholes down south who turned into corporate slugs. See. I told you i was never gonna give in to that. Which, of course, is why we're broke half the time. I do believe there is a happy medium. I haven't come across it, yet. But i will.

urlLink BBC NEWS | Americas | Wonderful world of Wal-Mart Whenever Wal-mart pops into the paper somewhere, i read it. Dale works at the one in town. It's the "best" job in town. Right now, it's the only job in town. They just expanded and are opening an LOF center, McDonalds, grocery section and something else. My friend Mike works for the one of the soda bottlers in town, and said people were lined up all through the store on Wednesday to get applications because it's grand opening is in March and they're actively hiring right now. Dale gets an IRA. He gets stock. He gets health insurance, and it was decent insurance until this year. They raised the monthly payment, and cut services to emergent services only. No preventative or anything. That's retarded, and in the long run i, personally, only see it costing them more money, and they will cut services again and raise the price, and then you might as well just get OHP cos you're already a third class citizen so being treated like one isn't so bad. (please note sarcasm) As far as i know, none of the local workers are involved in the suit against walmart about overtime and less than minimum wage. They had a pretty ethical store manager in there for the last two or three years. And the one before him seemed to be doing a decent job of it. I don't know, i don't work there, and i don't really no any of the other "associates". ____________ other stuff. "Automatic female envy" This is the cold shoulder tam and i get by maybe 1 of 20 women when we play somewhere. I don't know what else to call it. Its only present, really, in women who are there with their boyfriends or husbands or whatever. It doesn't matter how we look, what we wear, how we act. Somehow, they're immediately threatened by us. It doesn't happen enough that it really gets my goat or anything (and, heh, girlie if i really wanted your prime example of a total fuckin loser, i'd have him) but enough that a pattern is emerging.

urlLink Apeasing Hitler and Saddam Got the link from Instapundit. Saw that it was an Alistair Cooke article and felt i had to link to it, too. When i was a kid, we had an Alistair Cooke book on US history. Extremely good book, and i probably learned more about American history by the age of 7 from that book than four years of high school American history. The man must be in his 90s now. When he wrote the US history book, i think he was in his 50s or 60s. I had thought he passed away for some reason. I'm glad to see him still opining, still writing, still with something to say. And its cool to have the words of someone who is old enough to actually remember the world in the 1930s. Those people are being lost pretty quickly now. { I removed some sentences here. It's not self-censoring because i said something moronic, but because of privacy issues. I'm unsure where it stands in legality considering my particular line of work.} I have no problem with saying moronic stuff. I think its very important that the generations talk to each other. He draws some interesting parallels in the piece, definitely. Note to peace activists: the slogan peace in our time is not something to use on a placard if you want to be taken seriously. In fact, most of the placards I see at peace rallies are so tired, so freaking moronic, that i'm embarassed for the people carrying them. Last night i had a thought that struck me as weird. It seems like the peace movement of the 60s has stuck its head into the 00s, and i really have no problem with that. Protest for peace all you want. But it seems so many of the 60s people are just trying to re-establish their cred and relevance in the world. Its like having a 50-year-old mom who wears leather miniskirts and tube tops to drop you off at school in the morning when you're 15.
Probably gonna put some more arts up this weekend. woowoo. !

Friday's gig, while fantastic, was an acute excercise in self-inflicted pain. (notes to self): 1. The sweater dress is probably the second worse thing to wear on stage i've ever worn on stage. Wool/cotton blend irish fisherman style cable knit. Fucker must weigh 10 pounds wet. I know cos i soaked it sweatin my ass off in it. (Here's your sign, april) 2. The Krissy Snow boots... really, they're simply too small for me. Nothing like cramming your feet into sardine cans with 4 inch heels for 5 hours. (Here's another sign, April) 3. Even in a smoke-free bar, the glasses may be the way to go. I felt like my corneas were going to peel right off my eyeballs by the time i got home. 4: Bring glasses and contact stuff whenever you decide to wear the little plastic torture devices. A lot of the people who came out were actually from out of town. they're all going home stunned. No one believed we were local. Well, even the locals have interesting musical tastes, so nyaaah. We didn't all grow up in this cultural vaccuum. No really i haven't had so many compliments in one night, for a mere hour of playing, EVER. I don't understand why its a big deal to see a woman in a band doing something besides singing. I don't look at the gender of it anymore. we're all just playing stuff and doing what we do and some of us have boobs and some of us don't. It's a big deal, here, though i guess. I only know one other woman who plays the bass. speaking of women who play the bass.. Paz..Zwan.. ok i saw the Zwan video last night. Did someone start Billy Corgan on Prozac or something? That "honestly" song borders on "sappy love song". it had no balls. But neither did that 1979 song. Man, that's one boring fucking song. anyway, got some pictures and will put them on the band page sometime later this weekend. We didn't get any of us playing.. grrr anyway got too much to do tomorrow with getting set up for the Free Souls thing to deal with the webpage right away. I gotta go to sleeeeeep.

From an article in today's Register Guard about George Carlin (he's coming to town): "I view the whole thing as sort of entertaining," Carlin said. "My theory is that when you're born, you're given a ticket to a freak show, and some of us know that, and many people don't seem to know that; they participate in the freak show. "My fun is in observing the disintegration of this potentially wonderful species."

i've written a fantastic song. In my head, at least. I can actually sing the chorus of it, and i solidly hear the bass line that goes through the chorus. The rest is a little more difficult. The hardest part, for me, about writing a song, is getting it from my brain onto paper. Should brush up on the notation reading and writing, probably. Songs just appear in my head. I'll be standing around, and *woomp* a bass line appears out of nowhere... When i realize whats happening i find a pen, and scribble some stuff out. Maybe the proper chords, may just be a series of chords that just move with the effect i need, and then figure the real ones out later (this is retarded of me. I write music by interval i think). Sometimes the whole song just appears in my head, words, music and all. Sometimes it the bass first, then the words, then the rest of it.

i just added a link to Jesse Colin Young's site. While i was scrabbling around the kitchen for something to eat, and something to kill my chocolate craving (made fried eggs and a batch of mexican scratch for coffee instead), i was wandering around singing "four in the morning". I tend to sing that song a lot. I can make all the notes in it. Everything else is phrasing and timing. Cool as shit song, too. Not the Youngbloods version, thought that one's pretty good. JCY's is straight acoustic and screams "oregon coast" sometimes. It's the blues if i ever heard it. So i added his site. He has some new stuff on it for downloads. He also sells Kona. KONA. gotta repeat that. KONA! he owns a kona farm. I haven't tried his beans yet. But i'm going to. I adore kona coffee. Especially organically grown and processed kona. And there is a HUGE difference between it and store bought. Once you try it, nothing will be good enough. And you will happily plunk down $10+ a pound for this elixir of the gods. Jesse will also write back if you email him. Neat. Some other people that will if they have the time: Mike Watt. Jack Bruce. Jules Alexander. I've had small, ongoing conversations with some of my favorite artists, and one was resurrected after over a decade (was very happy to find Jules. After i heard about Dave, i was rather worried about the man).

Well, i was going to try to draw comparisons to some different groups. I started looking around. What i found confirms something i figured out sometime last year. on 9/11/01, every single political line that had been in place was blown to hell. There are republicans who are anti-war, democrats who are pro-war, aspects of the left espousing white supremacy and straight up nazi-ism, and aspects of the right defending the enemies. There are christians who say both cheeks have been slapped and its time to bring out the muskets, and there are christians who say "give them another chance". There are a few (very few, from what i see) pagans who believe its not about oil, and an ENTIRE COUNTRY who wants the oil (and its not the US...), but is standing around with its finger in its ass saying we're the empirical tyrants. Come to think of it, the green, earth-loving pagans seem to think its forgiveable for a certain man to set oil fields on fire, drain marshes and dump raw crude into the sea, because we will kill innocent civilians . Some days i simply have to tie a rope around my head to keep my jaw attached to my face.

There's something really rad about cruising around in a new red vette with a fine blonde woman. That'd be the owner of the car. Men stare. Boys stare. Women stare. Everyone smiles. She bought it herself, for exactly the reason i would: horsepower. Excellent handling (on dry pavement, at least). It's all the car any car needs to be. Unbelievable stereo system. Not sure how to explain it. I meet women with hi-performance cars, and usually their husbands have bought it for them as some kind of status thing. They drive them like crap. They fill them up with trash, whatever. I'm always stoked to meet another woman who appreciates horsepower. I would love to have another car with a V8 in it. My friend has a lot of faults. I hear about the faults from other friends. Thing is, she's much more like me than some of my other friends. The misunderstandings they have about her are ones they'd have about me, if i wasn't as good as being a social chameleon as i am (that probably comes from wanting good friends really bad, but never actually trusting other people enough to let them be those good friends). She's relatively new to the area, and hasn't quite found her niche among the locals. That's fine. I don't have one either. I stick out like a sore thumb, too. I use it to my advantage though, i guess. And she's aware of her faults, and actively works on fixing them, which is quite a bit more than i can say for some of the people who criticize her. Plus, it's really hard, i think, to find yourself in a very tightknight community as a new person. You find yourself with no one and no where to run to when you need to. All the ties are already made and you have to ingratiate yourself to those people. Fuck that. (that's where we both stand on that). Not gonna kiss some ass so someone will like us. We are who we are and we do what we do and those that don't like it, well, they know where to shove it. If they don't, we can tell them. When we meet people who are similar to us, or have had similar life experiences, there are certain nuances of speech and mannerisms and words that we pick up on that say "Here's another kindred soul". I can find those in my friend with the vette, she's a mirror of what i would like to be at 49 and she's said i'm a slightly different version of her at 33. There's a connection i have with her that i just don't have with a lot (ok probably most) of my other friends. She doesn't pine for her youth, or wear clothes for a 16-year-old. She has a certain class that's lacking around here. People are intimidated by her, and express it as dislike or whatever. Ok, been there. Felt it through high school and most of my 20s.. people are intimidated by me for some reason. But, if they only knew... I got called stingy with my emotions a couple of days ago. Yeah. If they only knew. So some friends i do certain things with, and some i keep at an arm's length away, and some i can hang out with all day long, never say more than 20 words, and still have a fantastic time. Each friendship has a boundary for me, based on certain odd qualities i've never been able to articulate. No one is closer to me than Dale. There's a descending order of closeness after him. all this... from riding in a vette all day yesterday. She had it running a few times, but she never actually put the pedal to the floor. I was hoping she would :P

Passed by the old "three-shoeboxes-in-a-row" triplex that Dale and i used to live in (Building codes?! What building codes?!). Looks like it caught fire. Not the one we lived in, but the one at the other end (A shoebox with two bedrooms...). A neighbor once punched a hole in her wall. We found the insulation was old newspapers. When we first moved in, the power wasn't grounded right. You touch a light switch, you got shocked.

Today was really nice. It never got above 60, but in the sunshine it was warm and nice. It was clear out, not too windy. And, i got to cruise around in this: (as a passenger, but still... hell yah!) Drove to Bandon and back, taking the back roads. Some fun shit. Makes up for yesterday, for sure.

o yeah and i need to get some Queens of the Stone Age. Yah, i'm behind, having just gotten Tools Lateralus... but, all in good time, my pretty. There's a fuckin ton of music out there and i have to listen to ALL of it. Or, at least as much as possible. Jeez, i had to talk to a raging full on tweeker tonight. gaaaah. What a pile of shit .
Yknow, at the very end of AC/DC's Dirty Deeds song, where whatsisname goes BLEEAARGH ? That about sums it all up right now.

off to drool on the pillow. I'm reading journey to the center of the earth right now, by Jules Verne, too. Not sure which of these books i'll read next. I'm getting down to the pile i haven't ever wanted to read, now, like "rebecca" and "Anne of green gables".

with every passing day without cloud cover, it gets colder and colder here. Tonight, its supposed to be in the low 30s. We have practice tonight, so that just means Jeff's drums will go out of tune about 40 minutes into practice, and then again another 40 minutes after he tunes. it means my bass will not hold its D string at the D, no matter how many times i dick around with it. It means for the first half hour or so, unless i keep my hands in my pockets all night long, my fingers will be too cold to get warmed up for nasty stuff like "I will survive" and "One Way or Another". It means i will have to take a handful of Aleve before practice, because the various minor crush injuries and breaks to my fingers are going to act up and hurt like hell tonight. Ah, well, what we do for our art, right? Hrmph. heheeh. Guess today i'll just kind of do stretching and warming up stuff on my hands and fingers throughout the day, or i will be so stiff by the time practice rolls around i'll only be able to play some stupid thing on open strings only.

the ravenous little green creature that is my ego is demanding to be fed. It's been hungry because we haven't played in a month. i just wonder, all the people who say Bush is an idiot, is he an idiot when he says Islam is a religion of peace, too? No, i don't really like him either, but if he is, as some people say, completely a moron, then perhaps it is time to stop defending Islam because, as the Pres says, it's a religion of peace. Sorry. I don't buy it. If Bush is an idiot, he's a complete idiot, and everything that comes out his mouth is utter idiocy, including his weak defense of our enemies. The hug-it-and-make-it-better camp seems to believe him on this one important point. okay! if he's just placating certain groups of people, then i think its just that much worse. Forfend, for we may offend the smallest blade of grass, so tread lightly. I'm going to make a comparison later today that i've been meaning to for a while. But first, must snuggle with my smart half.

looking over the mission list at the urlLink NASA site, i'm struck by the smiles on the faces of every single astronaut. They seem like the smiles of people who can barely contain their glee at being able to do something like be shot into space on the back of a rocket. I'm not sure i've ever smiled that way. Alright, i said i would shut up about it.

urlLink Astronaut Profiles Excerpts from each one: Lt. Col. Michael Anderson- "I take the risk because I think what we're doing is really important." David Brown - Brown, 46, soared into orbit on Jan. 16 with a flag from Yorktown High in Arlington, Va., his alma mater, that another graduate took up Mount Everest. "I'm going to get it a little bit higher up, but I won't have to walk as far to get it there," he said before his first spaceflight. Kalpana Chawla - She was a hero in her native country, which has launched satellites for years and is preparing for a moon orbit this decade. One Indian news agency even tracked Columbia's flight so it could tell readers the exact minute they could wave to the skies to hail their countrywoman. Laurel Clark - "She loved it," he said. "I'm just so glad she got to get up to space and got to see it because that had been a dream for a long time." (said by her brother) Col. Rick Husband- "They made the ultimate sacrifice, giving their lives and service to the country and for all mankind," Husband radioed from Columbia before the airwaves went silent. "Their dedication and devotion to the exploration of space was an inspiration to each of us and still motivates people around the world to achieve great things and service to others." (about the Challenger) William McCool- "There is so much more than what I ever expected," McCool told National Public Radio on Jan. 30 from the space shuttle Columbia. "It's beyond imagination, until you actually get up and see it and experience it and feel it". Ilan Ramon- "He wrote about the divine happiness of looking at Earth," she told Israel's Channel 10 television. "He wrote that he would like to keep floating for the rest of his life. That was the last sentence he wrote to us." And with this, I will leave it alone, and let others who write far better than i could hope to, say what they need to say. It's dark here now. The day is over. The Phoenix In a tower of flame in Capsule Twelve, I was there. I know not where they laid my bones, it could be anywhere, but when fire and smoke had faded, the darkness left my sight, I found my soul in a spaceship's soul riding home on a trail of light. For my wings are made of tungsten, and my flesh is glass and steel, I am the joy of Terra for the power that I wield. Once upon a lifetime, I died a pioneer, Now I sing within a spaceship's heart, Does anybody hear? My thunder rends the morning sky, yes, I am here. The loss to flame when I was man, now I ride her without fear, for I am more than man now, and man built me with pride, I led the way and I lead the way to man's future in the sky. For my wings are made of tungsten, my flesh of glass and steel, I am the joy of Terra for the power that I wield. Once upon a lifetime, I died a pioneer, Now I sing within a spaceship's heart, Does anybody hear? Julia Ecklar, c. 1983

urlLink The catalogue of UK Entrances to Hell I love urlLink The Pagan Prattle Going through this side reminds me of a part of a book, i think its Thomas Pynchon's Vineland . A bizarre book, all around. i've read it two or three times and have yet to make heads or tails of it. But anyway, one passage comes to mind. He's explaining about how, once upon a time, hell and earth weren't separated. there were entrances and gates all over (this inspired my story about the fishing trip of the gods that is on my regular page) hell and earth. And the inhabitants used to go on vacation in hell or earth and take pictures and hang out and things were maybe a bit warmer in hell but they were essentially the same. For some reason, after a while, people forgot about the gates, and they were covered by parking lots and overgrown with weeds and no one came to visit anymore. So. That's what i was thinking about as i read this. It may not have even been Pynchon... it may have been skinny legs and all, or some other book by ...who is it, Robbins? More i think about it, the more i think it must have been a Robbins book.

Wal-Mart is in its yearly CMN (Children's Miracle Network) charity campaign right now. The local WM does a lot of cool stuff. Blankets and pet stuff for the animal shelter, the CMN campaign, raising money for local charities and its own associates in financial straits because of medical problems,etc. So, i just got to thinking, i wonder if they'd be hip to putting up a box somewhere to donate goodies to the troops. Books, goofy time-wasting toys, snacks, etc. I will ask when i go grab the man from work later. I will look into where to go with it, too. urlLink Snarlydwarf :: Biting Kneecaps I'm inclined to agree with this guy, snarlydwarf. I know a few people who joined the military for the financial benefits, but i know far more people who joined because they felt it was something important and worthy. When i was younger i wanted to join the Air Force and fly fighter jets. I *really* wanted to. I had a conversation about with my uncle, who at the time had some 30+ years with the USAF under his belt and was a Master Seargent. He said my eyes were too bad and there was no way they'd let me anywhere near a plane, but there were other things i could do. Yeah, but i didn't want to DO those other things. I wanted to fly the freakin jets. I was probably 14. My father's side is pretty military. My grandpa was USAF, and i believe he served in WW2 in Asia, and my father's first guitar is somewhere at the bottom of a bay off the Vietnam coast. _____ The negative thoughts are like hobgoblins in the closet lately. I can't reach the light switch, and there's something rustling under the bed. I'm. Tired. Of. Struggling. and watching people who do nothing get ahead.

Perhaps one day i'll write something i feel is worth the carnival of vanities. (just out of nowhere. I like to write. I know i can do it well sometimes. SOMETIMES. And i know when i've done it well. Hasn't happened here, yet).

So, everyone, IS it weird enough yet? I just don't have any other way to express how surreal it all feels to me right now. And how my head (which is seemingly full of pudding right now, due to a head cold) gets slammed back and forth between "Life in this twisted, yet quiet, little coastal town" and "My gods, how can people even stand to watch the news any more". Talk about yer mental seesaw, brain yo-yo, etc. You know, you're standing outside the Star Trek club, talking with someone, about something trivial, and a thought enters your head, perhaps, "Jeez, that was one of our own guys that tossed that grenade", and it swims around for a while, as you nod and smile at the person you're talking to, and then you get deposited back into the previous reality. Sunshine. Fluffy clouds. Some traffic. A boat skittering across the bay.

and RE: protesters blocking streets, etc: When i lived in LA, Nashville and Phoenix, nothing, and i mean nothing stood between the 5 o'clock dash for the car and home, except a stop for a beer somewhere. Had there been people impeding my homeward progress, they would have found themselves with fashionable tire tracks across their clothing. I can only say how happy i am that i don't live in an area that was essentially shut down by these people yesterday. I've been known to gun the engine at pedestrians who take their sweet-ass time crossing against a light, play chicken with people who jaywalk and yell "get the fuck off the phone, assmonkey" at people in front of me. I can't even imagine my reaction to what happened yesterday. Dale might be able to tell you, since he's been the passenger most of the time, and tends to make me drive when we have to go to SF for some reason or spend time in LA. People think NY drivers are selfish assholes... i learned to drive in LA, and we're probably the most selfish asshole drivers on the planet.

attention ex-smokers: However you quit, did you find yourself yawning A LOT? Jeezus, i can't stop yawning. This has only been in the last couple of days. I mean last night when i went to bed, i laid there awake, yawning, for what seemed like hours. Lori cut my hair for me last night. It was TIME. I had just bleached it in expectation of redying it this week. Its been growing since i shaved it all off on 9/11/01. I had it trimmed once, and hacked at it myself once, but i've let it go on its own for awhile. but it was time to get the ends off because i hadn't, and i've bleached it like 6 times. So when i cut my hair, it gets all excited or something. it puffs out and i really can't do a THING with it for about a week. I look perma-blow-dried. Anyway, gonna probably dye it tonight. When we play on Saturday night, i will have scarlet hair again, with blue streaks in it, and we;'re going to dedicate Metallica's "Seek and Destroy" to the folks overseas.

ooh, joy of joys.. finally, a restaurant in town that isn't chinese food, mexican food or italian food. Yes, we have a mediterranean & middle eastern food restaurant now, and its fab. i went there for lunch today and had Turkish coffee (aquired taste, i'll have to get used to it again- made the mistake of sipping at it. Should have cooled it a bit, then shot it) Dolmas Felafel and babaganoj and i was momentarily in utter heaven. I didn't know what to do with myself. my taste buds were overjoyed. oooh, the tahini, the hummus, the odd texture of the grape leaves and the nearly perfect yogurt sauce (needed a bit of dill, but i'm not complaining!). I scarfed almost all of it and brought a bit home for Dale. then i put the rest of the babaganoj in with the yogurt, dumped it on a bagel and scarfed again. I'm gonna make sure Lori, Mike, Dale & I go out there for lunch sometime. I may just go there for lunch whenever the question arises. i'd HATE for it to disappear! _____ And lori and i had a sort of longish discussion tonight about the war, which we've never sat down together and talked about. She feels differently than i do, and that's fine. I told her i wasn't sure what happened, but there was a time when i would have been out with the anti-war protesters. I think 9/11 and having family killed on flight 77 may have been the starting point for what kicked me over. Then several other small things, like hearing the israelis are nazis, and the affiliations of ANSWER, and some of the (to me) other absurdities that they go on about. and what it comes down to, i think, is that at some point, the move to war reached its critical mass, and there simply was no backing down. And i, personally, was never able to figure out any way out of it, once they started, and hey, that prick deserves it anyway. Bullet to the head, hussein, you've lost your priveledge of counting yourself as a human being. I think "wolfie" is the true 'war monger' in the present administration. I think Bush is no more a Hitler than Clinton (but hey if you're going to base an opinon of Bush on what his grandfather did, might as well add Arafat to the list for what his uncle did), and its bizarre to call him Hitler when the man he's trying to pry from power openly idolizes Josef Stalin. no i still don't like bush much. I also think he's in an incredibly tough position, and i surely don't envy him, nor do i think i could do a better job. I do like Powell. I've liked him since the first gulf war. I'm not sure about Condoleeza. I haven't read enough about her, but i understand her as sort of a steady hand in the mania. I believe we (the US, as in government) have a responsibility to get the mofo out, since we put him there and yeah, it is our fault. Not sure if Iraq needs to be first, or be made an example of. Yknow, i do think about this stuff a lot, and try to figure out exactly where i stand on it. I don't have a flag. I didn't rush out and buy one. I know to question my government, and i know to question the "opposition". Opposition? Did i say that? With the numbers they claim, they are surely no longer the "opposition", so they ought to just drop that semi-victimy word for themselves and call a spade a spade, they are the slightly fringy establishment. They do what their parents and GRANDparents probably did. how rebellious! (*insert smirk*) And we are animals. And what is the definition of insanity? Doing the same thing over and over, expecting different results. What do we keep doing over and over, and why do things never change? when is the WTF am i doing moment going to kick in for human beings? Why are disgusting people like Idi Amin living the high life in foreign countries in exile? Can we just grab an island somewhere and put these creatures on it and just drop a few knives and crates of food for them and then forget about them? I would watch survivior if it featured Amin, Noriega, Hussein, Qadafi, on an island, and instead of voting each other off, they'd just have to... off each other. Last one standing gets to live on the island alone with no communication with the outside world until they croak. We'll check back in 20 years. Nothing more than a Swiss army knife and a couple pair of levis. Throw Malvo and his adult buddy on the island, too. And that freakin weirdo who grabbed Elizabeth Smart. Hell, i'd pay MONEY to watch that series. I'm a little tense. I'm a little edgy. I'm a little in the mood for the Deftones "Adrenaline" album, followed by ... hmm.. the Everything Went Black set by Black Flag. i'm a little in the mood for a long drive in the country at 70 mph, screaming along to the Master of Puppets album. damn. Its tuesday. Trash night. laters.

Anyone know if the 182nd Airborne from SC has deployed and where they went? Got a friend amongst them and we heard they were heading out, but nothing more. Ah, well, i'll keep looking. _____ Boobie update: MD found a second lump on the other side. So, off for another ultrasound, and excisional biopsy surgery is scheduled for 4/2. ____ Other update: So far, still doing really well on the quitting smoking thing. I haven't gotten down to NO CIGS yet, but i have not bought any packs of cigs and i do alright with 1 to 3 throughout the day. I've now caught a cold, so this may be when i just drop them entirely. Its difficult to go to a bar (which i often do to schmooze for gigs and have a beer or whatever), because i want a beer... and if i have a beer, i will want a cig, and then another cig, and another beer. Last night i took Jeff over to see Ea$y Money, a friends band, at a local bar, and i drank soda most of the night. Had one cig and a couple of drags off his. And thats how i think i caught this cold. But i got to see progress at the last appointment with the doc, with the caffeine and nicotine cutback. Since i first went, my blood pressure dropped by about 30 points or so- from 120/73 (which is kind of average, actually) to 95/60. Heart rate also dropped from the high 70s- low 80s to 68. I LOST 3 pounds, too. :) I imagine i'm burning a lot of calories just by the figeting i'm doing without a smoke.

a lot of people have those little javascript referrer lists. There's something really fuckin wrong with that thing. It grossly inflates the figures. I look at urlLink Salam's referrer list, and see that Nth (right here, y'all) has referred 10 people in the last 24 hours. I haven't even had 10 visitors in the last 24 hours. I surely haven't hit Salam's site 10 times in the last 24 hours. I find it hard to believe i'm the only person who noticed this. I noticed it a month or so ago over at urlLink One hand clapping . I mentioned it to him, and he took his down, and i don't know if he's put up another one. if you use this thing, pay attention to it if hits are important, because is not accurate, that i've been able to tell.

well, urlLink Greg is tired of blogthoughts about war. Frankly, i'm tired of sorting out my thoughts on it all. Every day, someone somewhere says something more absurd than the day before. On all sides. Glad i have no TV Jeff and i spent some time last night laughing at karaokers and a few words about this. We both think, why bother with a band, with all this crap in the world. We both answer ourselves with, there has to be something good, something entertaining, even in the most interesting or bizarre times, a few hours where the whole world is one room with cheap beer and happy people, and no aspect of reality dare intrudes for fear of being crushed by a red patent-leather six-inch platform boot with beer and puke on it. (this is also why i think entertainers should butt out of politics. Entertain us, and shut the hell up. its your JOB). We both think, why do we keep doing what we do, living our lives as if nothing is going on. We both think, what the hell is there to do? Do we drop everything and take a bike trip across the country? No. We plug away at what we do, let the little attacks of anxiety pop in, subside, and go away again, because when we were teenagers, we woke up often thinking "today, someone could be the one to push the button". That kind of fear is not alien to anyone born before 1975. Its just not something we've collectively felt since about 1992.

Boobie update; (aside-well, everyone else flings boobie around with aplomb, so i may as well jump on THAT bandwagon, if for no other reason than to maintain a little of my own sanity by injecting some humor into something that is extremely UNhumorous) Have to go back to Florence to meet with an MD on Monday. (aside- terrible time to have to make this weekly- so far- drive up and down the coast. Its only 46 miles, but the nature of the road sucks up just over a quarter tank on the toyota every time. With gas being what it is, grrr... put $20 in the tank yesterday and got.. GET THIS ten and a half gallons) They want to do a biopsy. (aside- please, just, yknow, apply some liposuction while you're at it, ok? I won't tell the insurance company if you don't.) So far, i really dig Peace Health (aside- i grew up in the Kaiser system, before it became Kaiser-Permanente, i think. It's a very special nightmare. Probably why i hate dealing with doctors and stuff so much NOW) At least I'm not one of the poor suckers staggering into Harbor General in Harbor City, CA. (aside- i once waited six hours in the ER there for an ex to have a broken nose set. To be honest, i'd never been so happy to hear a man scream in pain, because it meant we could leave, finally) ________ For two weeks, my truck was unable to start on its own power. The contacts in the starter were toast, and toasted themselves the day after we ran through the money we got for getting paid, which also happened to be about two days after we got paid. I had to bump start it, so anywhere i went, i had to park on a hill. if there was no hill nearby, i didn't go. But truck is all fixed, now. I joked with George at Coos Bay Toyota that i'm running a so-far unsuccessful experiment with the truck. I'm trying to kill it. Coos Bay Toyota is the best dealership i've ever dealt with, anywhere, bar none. I'm not even talking from a customer's point of view, but as a service station lackey who used to have to squabble with the parts departments to get parts, or the special goddamn tools to fix certain cars only available through the factory.

a large, soopa-windy storm is bearing down on us. Hopefully, i can get my work all finished before harborside has problems in Brookings, or we lose power here. The thing with these storms is that its usually dead calm in the hours leading up to them. dead calm. Like it is outside right now. It will be dead calm, then, out of nowhere, the wind will appear, blasting in at 50 mph. I give it until 11 or so. We're on a wind advisory, and anyone out at sea right now in anything that draws less than several hundred tons would have to be completely insane.

urlLink Susskins Central Dispatch: Clarity This is Zen. This is what i need to do. I can't seem to kick myself hard enough, though. I get my Zen fix in a lot of other stuff, and cant imagine getting it from the mundane, which, i guess, means i miss the point.

DAY 1 No cigs No coffee No pot No beer Why, oh, why the self-torture? I figure if i'm gonna quit one, i might as well quit em all. Jeff and i will be putting our utensils in a coffin-shaped box tomorrow and kissing them goodbye. For as long as we can, at least. Plus, its just too damn expensive to have ALL those bad habits. So, i'm drinking tea instead. I went from around (+/- on any given day) 2 packs of cigs a day to a coupla drags off the ones of friends yesterday... and i may continue that for a while, cos the cold turkey thing made me want to bash my head against a wall and made me quite unpleasant. Eh and i was told to switch to decaf. Yuck. I think i'll forgo the near pot a day i was drinking and do the tea, and once in awhile enjoy a nice cup of real coffee somewhere. I will miss the beer. However, O'Douls Amber is pretty good, and i like the taste, and don't always want a buzz. But... i will be pining for Red Hook and a Dove bar. I gained 30 pounds since i moved here (well, that was in 96, so that's not TOOOO bad.). Gonna do something about that, too.

yesterday in florence, as i was waiting to make the left onto 9th st, i noticed a small clutch of people hoisting a sign and walking south on 101. could barely read the sign, but i think it said "no war blah blah blah". I looked at my clock- it was 1:30. I wondered, shouldn't these people, like, be at work? Maybe not, its oregon, after all. Then, i realized most of them had that hunching stance common to high schoolers doing something they probably shouldn't... ok they probably should have been in school. But they were walking, and most of them looked like they needed the excercise anyway, uh, in a big fat way, i guess you could say. There were probably 8 of them. nah. i didn't take a picture. got other stuff on the brain, even though i had the camera with me.

tomorrow, or perhaps today, by the time this is posted... You ever go to some cliffs at night, and you go to the edge, but cant see the bottom because its dark, but you can hear the waves breaking? I've tried to not make a big deal out of why i'm actually heading into the mess of modern health s care, because i'm not completely sure. It could be just something mildly icky, or it could be something very scary. I hope i fall on the good side of karma on this one... but just to be sure, go out and buy a book of urlLink these for me.

urlLink Compelling without the Yelling Wren usually writes good articles. I wish i could say the same for a large portion of the the rest of the pagan community. For a group of people who take great pride (to the point of constantly pointing it out) in their individuality, they can be very sheeplike. A peek at the comments in any article on current politics in the Pagan News section is a good larf. Tons of indignation and umbrage. It's pretty hysterical sometimes. And the conspiracy theories, why.. you haven't seen such silliness since the last far right "anti-liberal" convention. What joke some of these people are.

When i get an annoying song stuck in my head, i want to smash said appendage into any hard, vertical surface until the song is battered out. When i get a song i like stuck in my head, its usually because i'm feeling akin to what it says, or i should feel that way. Sometimes, it's hard to tell, because lyrics are always hard to decode and interpret, because you didn't write them yourself , and your interpretation may be completely off from the writer's intention. Or the lyrics only make a little sense, and its the music itself that drives the sticking. So, Pretty Noose has been stuck in my head. For almost a week. Its so bad, i have to listen to it every time i drive somewhere. *click click* vrum, vrum chuggeta chuggeta hit the on button, ffwd to track 13, through the intro, haul down the driveway and if you happen to be next to me at the light at Newmark and Broadway, you'll be treated to the sight of a scarlet-haired woman trying her hardest to obtain Chris Cornell's vocals, as loud as she can, surrounding people be damned, I don't care what you neeeee-d . What a larf. Well, we gotta entertain ourselves somehow. I entertain myself singing in my truck, and probably entertain everyone around me with it.. "oh man look at that chick, she's totally jammin out, and BADLY". (car full of eurojappofoofoomobile racerboys laughing) Yeah well "I'm a big rock star so FUCK YOOOOOOO!" (from a live version i have of Soundgarden doing "earache my eye") But, anyway, with the various degrees of bullshit lately, i wonder what my brain is trying to say by clinging to that song. If you happened to read the band blog about a week ago, you may have seen a large portion of the bullshit i'm talking about. Her name is T. And she's the singer in my band. And i just scratched her off the friend list and added her to the persona non gratis (grata?) list. One can only take so much... When you're 26, its no longer excusable to act like a vindictive little high school idiot in regard to business . As a musician, its common courtesy not to scream at your band members at a gig, and not to talk shit about them on the band's webpage. No one has walked off stage yet, and no one has screamed at anyone else at a gig (oooh but i've come -->this Anyway, i left that up for a week or so. It ain't my personal credibility that suffered for it, oooh nooo, and that's good enough revenge for now, cos i made sure boatload of local people saw it. I took it down after a few days because it was time for the sideshow to come to an end. She removed herself from the "team" list, (at least i didn't have to), and i don't expect anyone will be seeing anything posted by her there again. She's just a person i know, that happens to sing for the band i play bass in. I hate doing that, but it's self-preservation, if you catch my drift. I'm not going to be subject to her emotional blackmail or moody whims anymore. Fuck that. No friend i have ever had has EVER, i mean EVER, treated me so goddamn badly that i decided it was time to just kiss them goodbye. Since i have to deal with her in the band, i'm going to be an adult about it. If it was the first time it happened with her, i wouldn't be so upset about it, but its not. I like to learn my lessons the first time. the second time... well, after the second time there ain't no third time. One is lucky to get a second chance from me. One gets no third chance.

urlLink Shadows This weeks entry in urlLink Photofriday .

and here's an expansion of something i though of earlier after reading urlLink Intricate Plot today. Almost all of the middle- and late 20th century's greatest photographers had one thing in common: their first cameras. Just about all of them started with a Kodak Brownie when they were in their early teens. Until the Brownie, photography had been mostly an upper-class person's hobby, with expensive, bulky equipment and the money to throw away on the trappings of developing. Suddenly, the everyjoe had something they probably had only dreamed of while looking at their relatives' daguerrotypes and cyanotypes. And so when you go through antique stores and thrift shops and find old family albums with the black pages and the model A's, almost all of the pictures were taken with a Brownie or Brownie knock-off. I have a couple of these, myself, and have not yet been able to find film for them. The next leap in image-grabbing was color, in the 40s, but the basic concept of taking a picture was still the same, and becoming more mundane. Now we have the combination of the internet and digital cameras, and it seems almost like a Brownie explosion. There are sites where you can store photoalbums, sell your pictures, online galleries, blogs, etc. You can see what its like where someone else lives or what some person in maybe India does in their spare time or what kind of cars are out there. Stuff you wouldn't probably even really "see" if you went there yourself. You can see things you never wanted to see, too, of course... yeah you can see a whole lot of that . But i was just thinking about how far photography has come in just over 150 or so years. And how long it took to get to the discovery of its principles. And what we do with it now.

Re: urlLink Gabby's deceitfullness (yer links arent working right. its blogger.. what do i expect..): heh. The best paper i ever wrote for any class was one i wrote in my 7th grade creative writing class. the final for the class was to write something like 10 pages about something that changed our life. I couldn't think of anything. I'm, like, 12, ok? What changes your life when your 12, if your a bored white kid living in middle-upper class suburbia? Nothin, that i could think of. So i wrote up this 10 page bullshit story. The sort of thing Robert Fisk would be proud to read... I hadn't had the anti-triteness beaten into me yet, and i remember this final was the epitome of 12-year-old girl writing. The ONLY paper i ever got a freakin "A+ Excellent" written across the top in that red felt pen, was 10 pages of bullshit. My teacher was amazed. My writing was "poignant, and exposed the raw edge of man vs. himself conflict and blah blah blah, something or other". You'd a thunk i'd written a bestseller. Then.. dammit... see you always get bit in the end.. she called my mom to tell her what a fantastic kid she thought i was, for this life-changing thing. And MY MOM was like, "WTF?!" about it... and i had to tell her i was full of shit and stuff. And my mom made me tell the teacher, and i got to keep the "A", but the teacher never talked to me afterwards. it was like i had betrayed her, or something... but.. geez, i knew what she was looking for, it was a "Creative Writing" class, and i gave her what i knew she'd grade high for. So, what i'm getting around to saying is i don't have any prob with Gabby making a buck off the teeming millions. Its what anyone who has some kind of talent wants, isn't it? Artists get the shaft: You starve if you stay "true" to your work, and if you dare try to make a buck, you're a sellout. Well, okay, some stuff is just schlocky (like... that painter of light guy) but daaaamn... wouldn't it be good to be schlocky and rich. You do the Chicken Soup thing, or the romance novel thing, or you write terrrible sci-fi for geek magazines or silly pop songs and you do your heavy stuff on the side.. OR you just get a big ol' charge out of writing crazy shit like that and then cashing a check for doing it... hahaahaha i think its rad.

Well. My eyes just popped out of my widdle head. I had a realization. I have a bore blog But that's ok, because, believe you me (as they like to say in places like Tennessee), if you lived in North Bend, Oregon.... You'd babble ceaselessly, too. You'd MAKE the 2-hour drive to Eugene just to have Indian food. You'd go batshit too if the best place in town to eat was a Sizzler (not no more though... ooooh no, now we have the fabulous "Yesterday's Cafe" in downtown North Bend, behind the library, where you can order such culinary delights as babaganoush ). I'd like to hear some of the locals say that word...i wonder if it would be anything like a Jersey tourist in LA, asking where "Seppleveeda" Boulevard is. (Sepulveda) But onward, you'd pick up an instrument just to entertain yourself. You'd take an interest in things you never thought you would... (For me its been trains, my friends kids, Magic the Gathering, 80s metal... how bad could it be?!) And you'd be up at the strangest hours, babbling ceaselessly to whoever is out there...

Well, i dunno if its the cephalexin that's making me feel like crap, or the cold that's making me feel like crap, but the point is... i feel like crap. Maybe i will feel better tomorrow. Its one of those irritating kind of burpy colds. With popping ears. 100 grit sandpaper throat. Going from the floor of the Mohave to the summit of Mt. Whitney, then back. In 10 minutes.

mm, yeah, so once of the incisions is infected, and i got a mild chewing out for using peroxide and betadine on it in an effort to help clean it. Yesterday AM the doc calls in an order for Keftabs to the WM pharmacy. I go in around noon to see if they're in. Not yet. Out of stock. Should be some in tomorrow. (today). Today i go in around noon. Out of stock. I talk to the pharmacist, because it seems there are bunch of DMV employees working at the pharmacy now. She says they will call and see if someone else can be dispensed, because no one in town seems to have the Keftabs. So i go back to get Dale from work, and go stand around the pharmacy/pseudoDMV again. No word back from the doc yet. I explain the prob... and that suddenly kicks one of them into gear. So i came home with cephalexin, which is the generic for Keflex. I wonder why i couldn't get them in the first place? Its some burly antibiotic.. i mean i gotta take 1500 mg a day for seven days. I can't imagine Keftabs being that much burlier.

urlLink The Smoking Gun: Archive- Sultanna Freeman Charles at LGF had this link up. I had to also. Sultanna has been photographed without her ... uh i think this is a chador... before, when she was arrested (and convicted) for felony aggravated battery of a foster child. My thoughts on this: As many who know me (who may or may not read this thing) my driving priveledges were suspended for nearly eight years for ... well... being an asshole. Suspended in three states. It was never my right , as her lawyers are contending that driving legally, that is, with a valid driver's license is a right and not a priviledge to drive. I think this is "Important Thing Number One" in any Driver's Ed class, neh? That if we're dumbasses on the road, our driving priviledges can be suspended or even revoked. So what's the point of a picture ID if you can't see a face to ID? I don't see this as any kind of slam on Islam, personally, and its annoying that its even in court. The answer seems very simple- have your picture taken without the chador and drive legally, or leave it on and don't drive. I've been upbraided for having different color hair than what's on my license, and told to have a new picture taken. Why drive with something like that on? You have no peripheral vision! Hmm anyway, Sultanna should shut the hell up and quit playing the victim. Its not a religious thing. It's an anti-stupid thing.

urlLink Oregon's top tourist attraction? A casino - The Register-Guard, Eugene, Oregon, USA We have a casino in NB, The Mill. It sucks. Nice concept. Executed badly. Its right on the bay front. On 101. It looks like the old lumber mill it used to be. One can wander through the slots and watch a certain specie of speed freak- the one who can't decide if they want to blow this $20 they won on trying for more or play it safe and buy a bag from the guy in the bathroom. When i first moved here, my thoughts on the place were generally along the lines of "nice place to lose your unemployment/welfare check". They have a hotel there, now. I haven't had the chance to check that out, yet. I guess they have spa rooms over looking the bay? woowoo i want one. I want to launch the canoe from the balcony. hey, though, we have the opportunity to turn into a forest-and-beach Vegas. yay.

I've been listening to doctors dictate for too long. Just ignore any "At some point" or similar stuff. You think teenagers are bad with "like" and "um"... I once counted... in a 50 page document detailing the history of about 20 patients, one doc said "At this point" 130 times. it seemed to average out to 3 times per page. (and i wish some of these guys would speak much more clearly when they mention medications and certain conditions. I'd be much less prone to freaking out if it were so. I got accused of mistyping one thing that sounded nothing like what the doc said. How does "chondromalacia" [kon-dro-muh-lay-shuh] sound anything like "osteochondritis" [ahs-tee-yo-kon-dry-tis]? Am i so stupid?! )

i started taking wellbutrin for the smoking thing. one side effect is dry mouth, and i figured ok i can handle that. I had no idea . I woke up at 3:15 this morning and had to pull my tongue off the roof of my mouth. There was nothing to drink in the house but the nasty tap water. I went to the store. gaaaah. Got the "dry mouth" under control only to be overcome by ravening thirst. If i wanted to feel like that , right, i'd smoke a big fat bowl. but the wellbutrin seems to be doing its job. As well as its original intended job as an antidepressant thing. (i can only sort of tell about that, i'm going on day 3).

urlLink The Falcon and the Fallout (LA Times mag article. Use cyberpunk/cyberpunk if it asks for username) A very old friend's elder brother gets out of prison. The story of Christopher Boyce and Andrew Daulton Lee is usually sitting in the depths of my head. I was too young when he was arrested to understand much about it. Chris was in some of my dad's classes. Chris' younger brothers were, too. I heard about them as i got older, from my dad. I was friends with one of them, when i was in, i think 10th grade. Brian. Brian's probably 5 or 6 years older than i am and i lost touch with him at some point. Between my dad and Brian, i got to hear interesting things about "The Falcon". I don't remember much of what they said, except that my dad said most of the siblings got a lot of the unwanted type of attention at school. Brian wasn't one to babble on and on about it, but occasionally you could get him to answer a question. But I've never read the book or seen the whole movie, "The Falcon and the Snowman". I think the reason is that it's weird to think of someone from Palos Verdes, who went to the same high school i did, had my dad as a teacher, etc, did something like what he did. I didn't know Chris was at Sheridan. If i had, i might have sent him a hello note. I'm twisted that way. A note that said HI. Say hi to Brian from someone he probably won't remember for me. So anyway, the story of Christopher is one i'm picking up really only now. As he is released. If he writes a book, i will eagerly buy it and read it. Local boy does bad. Way bad.

huh. my father got to show a guitar to Eric Clapton. Got to play it for him. Of all the... daaamn. I would have crapped my pants, mmmkay? And, because i'm a jerk, you think i would have asked about Eric Clapton? Heeeellllll no , I would have pestered him about Jack Bruce . "Hey man i hear you guys hate each others guts! Har har har! Jack's aged better than you have, but you've got Ginger beat... Why is Jack making such rad music still and yours sucks so bad anymore?" Biodad works at Arturo Valdez' guitar shop in Hollywood. Art's a cool guy, and he has a lot of neat stuff in his shop. All mariachi, flamenco, etc. instruments. There was a MONSTER acoustic bass guitar there when i was, and most of the guitars have cool multicolored nylon strings on them. If there was a website, i'd point you there. But i think Art's one of those guys who doesn't need a webpage . I mean, if dudes like Clapton roll into your shop to look at your handmade instruments, i think you're already where you need to be...

Pah. the guitar sounds like shit. Time for new strings. So happy these are 1/6th the price of bass strings. aaah. (though i think i have a set of $12 Martins on them right now..) Its *weird* to play a guitar, being used to the bass. I like the classical necks because they have the room i'm used to on them, between the strings. A lot of people say the necks are too wide. it is much wider than either of my basses, but it doesn't seem to be a problem. The radius is thinner, of course. I started bass before guitar, so i'm all screwed up, i guess. Been called "untainted by guitar" about my playing. When i've practiced for a few days, i'm an excellent rhythm player. But i couldn't squeeze out a lead of any sort if my life depended on it. I can pick with a pick on guitar, but not bass, and i play my bass with my fingers, but can't switch that technique to the guitar. Take me to the zoo, i'm a retard.

urlLink Eject! Eject! Eject!: MAGIC Ok i'm finally getting around to reading this. And i haven't seen bowling for columbine yet, either. (I can't bring myself to pay $7.50 for it). OK anyway... i've seen this mentioned in other critiques of the movie: " Littleton, Colorado is a nice, safe, upper-middle class neighborhood. Its the kind of place youd want to raise your kids. It is also home to a Lockheed plant, and Moore goes on the make the assertion that this climate of death from these weapons of mass destruction is responsible for the Columbine killing spree. Presumably the school shooters in other communities had to settle for magazines and websites of missiles to work up their Death Culture madness " I'm turning this over in my head. I have been. When i was a tyke (probably 4 or 5), i lived directly across the street from an active NIKE launch site, Fort MacArthur in San Pedro. I would sit on my porch in the afternoon, picking my nose or whatever, and watch the "army guys" play basketball. Sometimes, i'd wander across the street to the chain link fence and wave and yell "Hi army guys!". Once a month or so, there would be a grumbling in the earth and the missiles were raised from their underground silos and cleaned or inspected, i guess. (and i didn't go shooting anyone, after growing up in this "culture of death") In Southern California in the 70s and 80s, everyone worked in aerospace, somehow. At Northrup or Rexnard-Tridair or whatever. My friends had dads who worked "in the defense industry" and thats all any of us knew. They built battleships in Long Beach and airplanes in Carson and El Segundo and Torrance. Or they commuted to El Toro. San Pedro was probably, at any one time, 40% military personnel. (and i didn't go shooting anyone, after growing up in this "culture of death") After high school i worked "in the defense industry". I made skin fasteners for missiles. I worked with people making parts for the Stealth bomber. My boyfriend, at the time, made airplane doors for Boeing. I haven't shot anyone yet! and i actually was surrounded by the freaking culture of death! So were thousands, probably millions, of other kids! So anyway i read this crap about the movie, and that one bit always sticks in my craw. And i wanted to say this: Moore, if one Lockheed factory is a culture of death, you're a fucking pansy-ass . I freely explored Ft. Mac after it was decommissioned. I looked down its silos and walked through the pitchblack tunnels and investigated the old motor pool, and stood in the big gun pits- all of them, and climbed around on decommed howitzers, peered out coastal pillboxes, wandered through the barracks, lived in its prior (40s era) base housing, and i'm pretty freaking okay. (Well, relatively so. Others may beg to differ.) But thats all i got to say about that. nyaah. p-a-n-s-y a-s-s

Was just listening to some of the metallica i have. I had their stuff on vinyl once upon a time.. all Metalblade releases. Master of Puppets is probably my favorite Metallica album. It seemed on the verge of doing something fantastic. I've always thought this was Metallica at their best. ... And Justice for All was good, but it was missing something that MoP had. (Cliff Burton, perhaps...) The two albums prior to MoP were also great, but the production on them was weird. They sounded like they were recorded in a big, tiled bathroom. ( aside : When i worked at the car wash in town detailing cars, i'd usually have my bass or an acoustic with me. On my breaks i'd sit and jam in the bathroom, which had superb acoustics for an acoustic guitar). Among bass players, especially the ones who primarily focus on metal, the debate rages: Burton vs. Newstead: Who's Better? Well, Cliff is dead, so obviously we can only imagine how much further he might have come with his playing. Some people regard "Anesthesia (Pulling Teeth)" as The Best Bass Solo Ever, In The Universe. Period. I think at the time it came out it was pretty special. It's fun, and kind of hard to play. I know if we're playing somewhere and i goof off with some of the lines in that, there will be a small knot of 30-something dudes gathered around to watch. always . If i stop, they're devastated. Newstead is a different player. Not better or worse. His lines, usually buried deep in the mix, are not especially complicated, but the simplicity is what gives them their power. It's a phrasing thing, making the music breathe. Y'know, instead of doing notes to fill between kicks, you lay down a note on each kick, or in between them, or something. That's Newstead's style, where Burton's was to fill up the spaces. Newstead used "the spaces in between". (Tam asked what was important in bass playing once, and all i could think of was "the spaces in between") So, really, you can't compare to the two guys. One's dead and the other guy plays differently. Newstead's stuff with Echobrain was pretty cool. He sounded comfortable. He sounded like he was really digging what he was doing, and i'm really interested to hear what he brings to Ozzy's band. As well, i'm interested to hear Rob Castillo in Metallica. From the Funk of ST to the grind of Metallica... neat. .

Today, to say goodbye to June Carter Cash in my own way, I'm playing all the Carter Family stuff i have (including the fabulous "motherless children") as well as Big Sugar's whacked out version of "Motherless Children". Once i've gone through the list a couple of times, i intend to listen to my urlLink "Unchained" album by Johnny. My dad turned me on to this stuff when i was a tyke. I learned to appreciate it when i lived in Nashville. I got when i started playing. What a time to be recording though, when radio was all live. Going from station to station to have your song played until it got cut to a thick-ass piece of black shellac, or maybe red shellac. I think a lot of the old-style country guitar playing is underappreciated, in a big way. Maybe that's why learned "Cowboy chords" before i got to bar chords. (hah, i still can't play a bar chord.. how lame am I?)

urlLink Bombings may spur antiterror unity : csmonitor.com So, now, How many countries, after 9/11, said "we are all Americans"? welcome to the club, Morocco and Saudi Arabia. You are all Americans . Oldest member of this club, of course, is Israel. So, let's change that to "We are all Israel". On a certain level, that strikes me as hysterical. imagine , the countries that hate us, first saying "We are all Americans", and now having to expand on that with "we are all Israelis". I guess it was easier, if no less distasteful, to be American for a day than Israeli. Hmm. I don't even give a crap anymore why "they" hate us. "They" should get the hell over it. Its called collective self-esteem. Get some.

Liberty Meadows is once again a yard. It took one weedwacker, and two passes with the lawnmower to make it look like a yard again. We own neither of these necessary implements, so we borrow them. Borrowing sucks, so sometimes the yard never gets mowed, and we spend a whole summer with a meadow. This year i think it will be different. The blackberries are beginning to take hold in places they should not, so i have to be vigilant in poisoning the crap out of the ones that aren't where they're allowed to be. One season of letting these mofos go is asking for pain and suffering later. Leather gloves, you may ask? Pah. In the words of the blackberries, "Fie on thy puny leather.. mine thorns are many and sharp. Get thee to a falconer shoppe, and thou mayest survive your battle." The cats are unhappy, since their nice hidey-jungle is mostly gone, now. But they have great piles of grass to lay on, so i guess that makes up for it somehow.

This is one of the things that makes me like it here. It's probably one of 5 things. Last night i took Djeef up to the urlLink Lakeshore Lodge in Lakeside to see my old band play. That band never really had a name. Sometimes they were Bud Shake and the Babe Magnets (funny name for a band full of dudes nearing 60), sometimes they were Spank Spike and the Nubtones. Sometimes they were just the Tavern Band. Anyway, they're the Millicoma River Band now and they play regularly at the lodge. So we went up and i had forgotten my ID. We went in anyway (cos its a 12-mile drive BACK) and i didn't need it. At the front door, we were accosted by four people i knew. A little further in, five people. All in all, i knew 21 people at the Lodge last night. Out of 35 or so. That's what i like. The big fish in a small town feeling. There were some people there who saw ML way back when we only knew 10 songs and played at The Homestead last year. They recognized me only because of my hair. (probably one reason i keep it scarlet... people don't forget me). But then they went on and told all the people THEY were with how great our band was. Thats something else thats funny. When i go see other bands, there is usually at least one or two people who have seen my band, and then suddenly the other band is ignored for the night and these people want to know about me and ML. And i'm always really surprised when people tell me what a great bass player i am. Part of me thinks, "Sucker. I'm mediocre at best". and part of me just feels great for being a mediocre player that people think is a really GOOD player. My playing ability drifts around. If i feel inspired to do a lot of playing, i get very good for a while and make leaps and bounds of progress. If i don't, like i have felt for the last two or so years, than i don't practice much at home, i don't pick up many of my instruments, and i don't care if i make mistakes because like everything else, it doesn't matter. I dread the winters here.

i'm actually a little surprised (in a good way) that no one has jumped on the Richard Petty post and pointed and laughed at me. Yesterday on my way back from Bandon i was pondering the sideburns issue. I saw a dude just a little younger than me with sideburns. I've always wondered this about fashion- it seems that the designers and movers take the stuff that was popular when the present late-20s or 30-somethings were kids and make it new again. Its some sort of sick nostalgia or something. Now i see that bits of the 80s are forcing themselves into fashion again. Prairie skirts. Ruffly prairie shirts. I see it and i think "yike! 1982!". Capri pants are a rehashing of a rehashing.. except now they're low-riding capri pants. I'm watching for espadrilles... Hell, even late-70s ealy-80s punk rock stuff is getting fashionable. Bondage pants and jackets, plaid pants, etc. (recently saw a bondage jacket paired with bell-bottoms... gag me with a spoon) One of our friends has a girlfriend who i secretly call "Little MIss Hot Topic", because it looks like that's where she spends all her money. I can't really talk, of course. the only time i was ever "in fashion" with my clothes was when "grunge" was the look. So i can say for about nine months of my life i was actually wearing fashionable clothes. The fad came and went, and still i had flannels, jeans, boots and tshirts, because thats what i always have and always wear. Built for comfort, not for speed. It was hard to run from the cops while being MIP with stiletto heels on.

There seems to be, floating around in the B'sphere, questions pertaining to Salam Pax, again. Some have said he's a Ba'athist. How does he post to his blog if there's no power? etc etc.. I just spent a good hour going through the archives for the present Where is Raed blog. (not the first one, yet). There are some things he has said that make me question the questioners. Some things make me wonder just how fucking short the memory of some people is. In the entry from when he returned, he mentions little places offering internet and email access for outrageous prices. So, indeed he may not have power where he is, but he may be using these places to post from. Somewhere in the blog, and i could have sworn it was in the new part, he mentioned someone in his family (his mother, i think) celebrating a heretofore banned Shi'a holiday. How many Ba'athists were Shi'a? In another entry, he takes a relative (of his parents generation) to task for supporting the Ba'athist revolution in the 60s, forcing them to acknowledge its folly. Yah, some hardcore party member, there, eh? Salam consistently makes snide remarks about Saddam Hussein, and in one entry specifically says the man has no ablutions to wash the black water from him, (the "skham wijih" entry), meaning Hussein's shame at what he did to Baghdad during GW1. He bags mercilessly on the misguided human shields. Seems that any good Ba'athist would be adoring them. Conclusion? Ain't got one. I really don't know enough about Iraq or the Ba'athist party to say one way or the other. But its hard to believe a party member would just blatantly make fun of the party like he has. Even taking into consideration the concept of taqiyeh... I havent delved into the archives of the old blog yet. But the accusations have me curious, especially because i don't read into the blog like others have. There are small things.. small things you notice that don't necessarily add up to the accusation. Small things in the writing and his English. Is he stringing Americans along? I don't know. Should people who have links to his site take them down? If he is a party member? If he is, then all the more reason to leave the links up, and here's why: To sweep a party member under the carpet is to burn books by Nazis. We all know the idealogy is disgusting. But its not something we should ever forget. So even though the information is distasteful, offends our sensibilities or makes us cringe at what people are capable of, the information needs to be out and available so we can cringe at it, so we can see the folly of it and the danger in totalitarianism. So we never forget. Its why the Jews have holocaust museums and Rememberance Day. If Salam is a Ba'athist, then here, with his blog, we have a glimpse into the mind of a Ba'athist. That on its face is what makes it worth keeping a link to it. RE: the blog. That's (the site) up the Coos River, some 8 miles past the tavern. I've camped at the site before. __- On Sunday, two local teenagers were killed in a crash east of Coquille. There were 5 people packed into a Daihatsu Rocky with a 3-inch lift that drifted off the pavement and down a ravine. The front passenger and the driver were killed. The paper showed a picture of the Rocky after they pulled it out of the ravine. I find it very difficult to believe anyone made it out alive. It's an unrecognizable mass of twisted purple metal, now. The passenger killed was the best friend of L's youngest daughter. No moral of the story. It's just sad.

urlLink Palos Verdes Art Center Raffle Home Damn. I think i'll plunk down some dollars the next time they do this. Looking at this house is weird. I miss houses like this. "Nice" homes here are chock full of shoddy construction that looks good from a distance but not up close. But even houses designed by architecture students (one of my friends lived in a house that was) were really well designed and finished. Part of me desperately wants to go back to PV and be able to afford one of these places (I'm frankly sick to death of being surrounded by poverty and slapdash shacks). Part of me recoils at the very thought. And the part of me that never shuts up starts working overtime scheming of some way to get there. (The "rational" me repeats, over and over, "college, babe. Go back".) The thing about being a 7-year-old with an overactive imagination in a place like this was you lived in a world of castles. I lived in an apartment, but most of my friends lived in these fantastic monstrosities full of cool stuff. For some reason, this reminds me to call my friend Sue. I have a product i need to discuss :)

Dale and i went to see X2 yesterday. It was pretty cool. I know nothing about the X-men. I didn't see the first one. But it was pretty cool anyway. One complaint, and i suppose this can be made of any movie taken from a comic... it was kind of predictable. You knew as soon as you saw a dam, the dam was going to give out at some point. And regarding the dam, (wont give away the movie here), i don't understand why the ice-guy didn't just stick his hand out and use HIS power, rather than that telepath/telekinete chick doing what she did. Dale gave me a rundown of a sort on the X-men comics after the movie. Good to have a guy like that around. :) I mentioned it must be a really cool time for diehard comic fans, because film technology has finally gotten to where it can render these comic-worlds in a way thats realistic. Looking at the Flash Gordon series of the 50s and then the movie from the 70s, and then X-men 2, is to watch visual technology make huge leaps and bounds, with perhaps the defining point of a big jump being the original Star Wars. That movie enthralled because of its effects, which were completely new at the time. I still think Glenn Danzig would have made the quintessential Wolverine. But Glenn doesn't act, so, oh well.

This post is specifically for egypt , but any of y'all can read it :P On playing music in front of people : Seems terrifying, doesn't it? I mean.. you get up with your guitar in front of a crowd with a lot of booze in it, and you pour your heart and soul out for 2 to 4 hours. The first time, hell yeah, it was terrifying. But every time, it got easier, and it got easier in new ways. Fact is, though, you don't pick up an instrument and stick with it, even learning to play other instruments, for six years without, at some point, thinking, "I really want to share how excited i am about this chunk of wood and wires with other people". It becomes something you have to do. Not because people tell you to, but because it feeds you and you thrive on it. After a show, everyone loves us. Everyone hugs us. Everyone says "you guys sound great". People want you back. They want to PAY US to come back. How cool is THAT? To get paid for whacking away at some strings and bebopping around and maybe yelling into a mike a few times... wearing odd clothes and having funny hair... My dad (a very staid, rather conservative type person, quite different than my father) and i had a conversation about it one day, and that's what i told him. That its fantastic to go act like an idiot for a few hours, and then have someone hand you a wad of dough for it. And he thought about it a few minutes, and then he agreed. Some people are completely different on stage than off stage. IRL, i'm fairly shy, rather introverted, don't say much. (I just have a penchant for funky clothes, is all). But you get to put this "costume" on when you play. You can be anything, anyone, you want to be. That kills the fear of getting onstage, you put on this costume of someone who loves to be the center of attention. The other thing that kills it is that, hey, if i make a mistake, no one is really gonna care, as long as i'm playing music and providing them with the beat to move their feet to.
